text:
If you have any results/stats from those engagements, consider elevating those over the duration. For example...

• Turned around 500+ word SEO focused articles on short timelines, contributing to MoM traffic growth of x%

elements.text: If you have any results/stats from those engagements, consider elevating those over the duration. For example...
Turned around 500+ word SEO focused articles on short timelines, contributing to MoM traffic growth of x%

text:
Hi everyone! Quick question on pricing for a freelance content project.

I've got my rates pretty well laid out for writing original content, but I'm curious what I should charge for content refreshing. The task at hand would be to refresh pieces of 1800-2500 words, paraphrasing the existing content (it's going onto their sister site) and replacing any examples w/ new/original examples I find.

Since it's a rewrite and doesn't require any original interviews/research (aside from new examples), what should I be charging?

Thanks in advance!

elements.text:
Hi everyone! Quick question on pricing for a freelance content project.

I've got my rates pretty well laid out for writing original content, but I'm curious what I should charge for content refreshing. The task at hand would be to refresh pieces of 1800-2500 words, paraphrasing the existing content (it's going onto their sister site) and replacing any examples w/ new/original examples I find.

Since it's a rewrite and doesn't require any original interviews/research (aside from new examples), what should I be charging?

Thanks in advance!

text: Hey <@U024A8928AW> whenever I have been asked to be a part of such projects, I usually charge based on the hours spent in rewriting, editing, or re-doing the content piece rather than charging for the research or words written.

elements.text: Hey

whenever I have been asked to be a part of such projects, I usually charge based on the hours spent in rewriting, editing, or re-doing the content piece rather than charging for the research or words written.

text: I would argue that rewrites are just as much—if not more—work than writing the original piece. Kind of like how good editing takes longer than writing. If the client is ok with it, and you can help to sell that concept, I would charge the same amount.

elements.text: I would argue that rewrites are just as much—if not more—work than writing the original piece. Kind of like how good editing takes longer than writing. If the client is ok with it, and you can help to sell that concept, I would charge the same amount.

text: I agree with Jenn. Rewrites are equal work, so you should charge the same amount.

elements.text: I agree with Jenn. Rewrites are equal work, so you should charge the same amount.
Thanks

text:
Hello everyone! I’m part of the Marketing Leadership Team at Women in Fintech and I’m sharing this event in case it’s helpful for anyone here:

* *:sparkles:*Virtual Marketing + Growth Recruiting Mixer*:sparkles:* *for members of our community on Feb 17 from 2-4PM PST!!!!! :star2::tada: Attendees will have the opportunity to *meet directly with recruiters* from companies like *Juniper Square, Chime, and Vouch Insurance* (and more) for a series of paired 1:1 chats to learn about current opportunities and openings!!! Even if you’re not actively looking for a new role and just want to learn about new jobs out there, this is for you!

This event is best suited for _attendees with prior experience in Marketing and Growth roles_ (although prior experience specifically at a fintech is not necessary.)

Attendance is on a first-come, first-serve basis and space is limited! If you’re interested, *please email (<mailto:jenny@womeninfintech.com|jenny@womeninfintech.com>) with your resume and LinkedIn, and I’ll send you the registration link!*

(and more) for a series of paired 1:1 chats to learn about current opportunities and openings!!! Even if you’re not actively looking for a new role and just want to learn about new jobs out there, this is for you!

This event is best suited for
attendees with prior experience in Marketing and Growth roles

(although prior experience specifically at a fintech is not necessary.)

Attendance is on a first-come, first-serve basis and space is limited! If you’re interested,
please email (
jenny@womeninfintech.com
) with your resume and LinkedIn, and I’ll send you the registration link!

text:
Question for leaders of content orgs at startups, if your team drives significant business results: Do you get meaningful equity for your work?

Why I ask: I'd like to see more content leaders get equity, because if you're building a function that contributes significantly to growing a business, you should share in the success of your company.

Not sure whether folks are comfortable discussing this topic, but I think it's important to.

For context: I've worked in the startup / venture capital world for eight+ years and negotiated for meaningful equity in both of my roles. I wouldn't have taken either job without that, given what I was expected to contribute and the risks I was undertaking, especially in joining an early stage startup.

elements.text:
Question for leaders of content orgs at startups, if your team drives significant business results: Do you get meaningful equity for your work?

Why I ask: I'd like to see more content leaders get equity, because if you're building a function that contributes significantly to growing a business, you should share in the success of your company.

Not sure whether folks are comfortable discussing this topic, but I think it's important to.

For context: I've worked in the startup / venture capital world for eight+ years and negotiated for meaningful equity in both of my roles. I wouldn't have taken either job without that, given what I was expected to contribute and the risks I was undertaking, especially in joining an early stage startup.

text: Every startup I’ve joined has provided equity and performance-based compensation for all employees. Meaningful is a tricky word. Most companies have set amounts of equity they provide at various job levels. In my experience you can negotiate a bit, but not a lot. After working at multiple startups and experiencing only one exit, I definitely prefer cash in the bank over lottery tickets - so salary needs to be competitive and performance-based compensation significant.

elements.text: Every startup I’ve joined has provided equity and performance-based compensation for all employees. Meaningful is a tricky word. Most companies have set amounts of equity they provide at various job levels. In my experience you can negotiate a bit, but not a lot. After working at multiple startups and experiencing only one exit, I definitely prefer cash in the bank over lottery tickets - so salary needs to be competitive and performance-based compensation significant.

text: (I haven’t yet hit VP-level at any of them, though. I know that a lot more equity possibilities and negotiation power unlocks at that point.)

elements.text: (I haven’t yet hit VP-level at any of them, though. I know that a lot more equity possibilities and negotiation power unlocks at that point.)

text: I got tons of equity at my last company. It was pretty easy, actually. They told me that most people simply don't ask for it outside of the set executive packages so they didn't have a structure in place. But I made it a point to ask for it at least annually when I was getting salary increases and then each time I got promoted. I left with 21,000+ shares... I've also seen more places offering bonuses to content roles, which I felt was lacking in the past. Content can certainly be tied to lead gen if all the tracking measures are in place so why not get paid for it the same way the paid teams are? I think the important thing is to ASK since it seems like a lot of people aren't asking.

elements.text: I got tons of equity at my last company. It was pretty easy, actually. They told me that most people simply don't ask for it outside of the set executive packages so they didn't have a structure in place. But I made it a point to ask for it at least annually when I was getting salary increases and then each time I got promoted. I left with 21,000+ shares... I've also seen more places offering bonuses to content roles, which I felt was lacking in the past. Content can certainly be tied to lead gen if all the tracking measures are in place so why not get paid for it the same way the paid teams are? I think the important thing is to ASK since it seems like a lot of people aren't asking.
Great tips, thank you!

text: At Lattice, I got a generous package when I started. I made sure to ask for what I wanted, especially because I was comparing their offer against another offer that was decently generous but not as much as I wanted. And since I wanted to go to Lattice more, it worked out well! Then each time I've gotten a level promotion (not always a title change), I receive an additional grant.

elements.text: At Lattice, I got a generous package when I started. I made sure to ask for what I wanted, especially because I was comparing their offer against another offer that was decently generous but not as much as I wanted. And since I wanted to go to Lattice more, it worked out well! Then each time I've gotten a level promotion (not always a title change), I receive an additional grant.

text:
Agree on asking, no matter what your level.

I’m going to share some equity basics, in case they’re useful to other content folks:

• It’s important to understand how much of a percentage of the company you’re actually getting (or getting options to buy). For example, say they issue 1 million shares and you own 100,000. That’s much better than if they issue 10 million shares and you own 100,000.
• Your strike price also matters, because you potentially profit from the spread between a sales price for a share and how much you have to pay for it (that’s the strike price). There’s no guarantee that your options will end up being worth anything, though.
• Depending on which stage you join at, there might not already be levels and an associated range of equity. The earlier stage the startup, the more free they tend to be with equity — being an exec isn’t necessary. Mostly, they’re compensating for the risk you take by joining early. Of course, this varies by company.
• Worth noting: Even after startups set levels and ranges, everything is still negotiable, depending on supply vs. demand for your skills and how badly a company wants you. That doesn’t require being an exec. It’s all about how much potential business value you’d add. Like there are IC technical or product folks who are so valuable that they have negotiating leverage. This is harder for content people in general, but varies with perceived value.
• Most startups fail, so depending on your comfort and confidence level, you might want to weigh cash more. But I’ve worked with a number of financially savvy people who valued equity more, as I do. That’s company dependent, of course, and varies with individuals’ personal finances and risk tolerance. 
• It helps to know how to pick better startups, and relatedly, if you’ve built a strong track record in your roles, you tend to get recruited more often by better startups. That’s because they figure if you’ve succeeded before, you stand a better chance of doing it than folks who haven’t proved themselves yet. Companies will pay more for lower risk.
• Past really early stage, many startups offer equity to all employees. Depending on how much cash you get, equity will vary. But companies will always try to compensate at market value. So for instance, if your market value is $100k annually, then they might give you $90k in cash and $10k in options (or some other combo that totals $100k). Logically, they won’t go over your market value, or they’d be overpaying you.
• Of course, market value and hiring aren’t scientific, so sometimes perceived value can influence what employers will offer. Some people come across as more competent and negotiate better, so sometimes they end up making more. (Bias can affect pay as well, course. That potentially includes race, sex and age.)
• You can never control others’ prejudices, but you can build strong negotiating skills. That’s worth noting for anyone who’s not comfortable discussing compensation — they’re skills worth learning.
FWIW, as a content leader, I’ve negotiated for a seat at the exec table (at NerdWallet, because I knew I’d need that to deliver significant business value), cash, equity, annual bonus, signing bonus, title and moving costs. (Currently, I get the venture capital version of equity — carry, which allows me to participate in the returns of startups we invest in.)

During both of my jobs in tech (my first career was in daily news), I’ve received increases in equity even when I wasn’t being promoted, simply because they wanted to retain or reward me. That can happen with various people at startups, across functions. I also got increases in equity when promoted. I originally started at director level when I changed careers and I negotiated equity even then.

Just remember: Any “rules” or practices involving equity were decided by people and they can change them or make exceptions if they think it makes business sense. Nothing is etched in stone.
